I have spent all my patience a great while

very earnestly: but nothing so muche as my pri-
vat estate. If importunitie would serve, I
have written about it fower or five times.
For an answear at first, I was bidde to at-
tend till sommer were past: and next till
an other were founde to succeede me: after
at I was willed to tarie till
e spring: and
nowe at last I am told,
at as long as this
Peace is in daunger of a Parle, I can not be
spared. Once
e spring is at hand: and I
thinke this Peace will come to nothing: or will
prove litle better then a paltrey practise of
e Spaniard, to gette advantage in dealing w
t
